text:
In markets characterized as monopolistic competition, oligopoly, and monopoly, there
is no well-defined supply function. This is because under all three of these market
structures, firms face downward-sloping demand curves. In each case, the quantity
supplied is determined by the intersection of marginal cost and marginal revenue, and
the price charged is then determined by the demand curve the firm faces. We cannot
construct a function of quantity supplied as a function of price as we can under perfect
competition, where price equals marginal revenue. The quantity supplied depends not
only on a firm's marginal cost, but on demand and marginal revenue (which change with
quantity) as well.
